intro: Achyronia cinerascens, commonly known as the ash-gray mallow, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton, and is characterized by its showy, pink to purple flowers. The plant has palmate leaves with five to seven lobes, and its stems are often covered in a fine, grayish pubescence. It thrives in arid and semi-arid environments, often found in rocky soils and open woodlands. The species is known for its drought tolerance and ability to bloom throughout the growing season.
